rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The chemistry of methyl bis-B-chloroethylamine and related compounds : The deacidification of RDX-B.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: At low pH, the dimer of methyl bis-β-chloroethylamine (“S”) undergoes hydrolysis of its β-chlorines at a rate independent of dimer concentration (SNl mechanism).This dimer reacts with S203= in a second order reaction, one S203= replacing one Cl-. (SN2 mechanism) In acetone-water, “S” dimerizes at a rate independent of “S” concentration. With increasing water concentration, a simultaneous increase in E and rate occurs. At low temperatures dimerization is the main reaction with some hydrolysis. The hydrolysis of the SH+ ion in a variety of acids in excess shows inhibition by both H+ and Cl-. Mechanisms are proposed for the reactions studied. Deacidification of RDX-B has been found possible by heating the solid in the systems nitrobenzene-water and TNT-water. Deacidification is also possible by heating RDX-B dry or in water slurry above 1200C. The acidity in RDX-B is not due to HNO3 or Ac2O, and only partly due to HOAc. The acidic component is mainly some compound, as yet undetermined, which readily hydrolyses to give N20, CO2, and other products of non-acidic character.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The thermal detonation of lead azide.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The minimum detonation temperature of dextrjn and service azide is sharply critical (within 1°C.) for a given batch., and may be raised by compression, wetting with butyl phthalate, or increasing the surface/volume ratio of the charge contain er. Large single crystals of lead azide have a lower minimum detonation temperature than have smaller crystals. These facts indicate that self-heating is a factor in the detonation of lead azide, the rate and amount of self-heat being influenced by the inter-particle thermal conductivity of the charge sample. The induction periods preceding detonation at a given temperature are reproducible within experimental error, precludin~ the possibility that thermal detonation of lead azide is caused by the collision of material or energy chains, which would produce a more random distribution of induction period data,.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The viscosity instability of solutions of high polymers.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Three polymers were aged in several solvents at 6o 0c·with varying amounts of iron chloride added, in the presence of and absence of oxygen. The results showed that the phenomenon of viscosity instability is of a general nature, occurring with all polymers in all the solvents. Dissolved oxygen reacts with the polymers causing viscosity decreases. Iron salts catalyze this reaction, and also combine chemically with the polymer to cause viscosity increases and gel formation. That the above changes are due to a change in molecular weight of the polymers has been demonstrated by measurement of the intrinsic viscosities of recovered polymer samples. An interpretation of the change in the shape factor has been attempted.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Characterization of polyvinyl acetate by molecular weight determination.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The need for an absolute method to follow the changes in viscosity shown by polyvinyl acetate in various solvents, initiated a study of osmotic methods for determining molecular weights of this polymer. A Carter-Record type of cell was found less convenient than a modified form of the Van Campen osmometer. Number average molecular weights for polyvinyl acetate determined with the latter did not agree with reasonable predictions of intrinsic viscosity measurements when Carter-Record type membranes were used. Reasonable molecular weights were obtained for Gelva 15,45,150 and 360 with caustic treated membranes.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The synthesis of 1,1-diphenylethane from benzene and acetaldehyde.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The condensation of benzene with acetaldehyde has been studied in the presence of a variety of condensing agents with a view to increase the yield of 1,1-diphenylethane by means of a more effective and more economical condensing agent than concentrated sulphuric acid. The dlphenylethane is a source material for styrene useful for the manufacture of synthetic rubber and plastics. The yield of 1,1-diphenylethane from the benzene-acetaldehyde condensation has been improved from 40-50 per cent obtainable with sulphuric acid to 70 per cent with boron trifluoride.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: War research. : Kinetic studies on the conversion of D.P.T. and P.H.X. to H.M.X.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: P.H.X. was found to precipitate spontaneously in the very slow D.P.T. AcAn reaction in the absence of ammonium nitrate at 35°C. H.M.X. and by - products are formed at the same rate and in similar yields from both D.P.T. and P.H.X. at 25°, 30° and 35°0., in the presence of ammonium nitrate. 'I'he same conclusion was reached when the addition of ammonium nitrate was delayed for various lengths of time in the D.P.T.-H.M.X. reaction. It was concluded that D.P .T. yields H.M.X. through the intermediate formation of P.H.X. Conclusions were dravm as to the stability of the various bonds of the D.P.T. and P.H.X. molecules and mechanisms of reaction were postulated for both AcAn and H.M.X. productions.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The origin and development of the Prometheus myth.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the course of his discussion of Aeschylus' use of the Prometheus myth, George Thomson has observed that "this myth has a history of its own". It is the purpose of the present study to trace this history, as far as that may be ascertained from the materials at our disposal. In claiming this purpose, the author desires to differentiate his task from that of the many compilers of handbooks to whom he is indebted. It may Suffice for a compendium of Greek mythology to present all the variant forms of a myth, while making adequate reference to the literary sources of such variants; indeed, the limitations of space may well excuse any encyclopaedist from doing more than this within the compass of a single volume. A more ambitious work, extending into several bulky volumes, may even arrange the literary references to any one myth in chronological order; but that does not give us the history of the myth. The aim of this present treatment is not simply to chronicle the many literary allusions to Prometheus, but also to attempt some explanation of the more significant stages in the development of the myth.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mythology -- Greece.
Prometheus (Greek deity) in literature.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The prediction of success in technical school courses.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the Fall of 1939, a request was received by the Department of Psychology, McGill University, from the Vice-Principal (Officer in Charge of the English-speaking Division) of the Montreal Technical School, for assistance in establishing a screening technique which would select with greater accuracy from the increasingly large applicant list, a group of candidates, equal in size to the accommodation facilities of the School's classes and shops, likely to succeed in the four-year Technical (Day) Course. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: TECHNICAL SCHOOLS.
PSYCHOLOGY -- MENTAL TESTS.
Psychology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of alloxan diabetes mellitus on experimental cholesterol arteriosclerosis in the rabbit.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: As social and medical progress have gradually emancipated mankind from many of the more acute and fatal diseases, so have the diseases associated with old and middle age come into prominence. Among these latter is arteriosclerosis - a disease which, with its sequelae, has assumed major importance as a cause of death and physical incapacity. Study of' the disease has yielded an immense amount of information but, up to the present, little understanding of its fundamental properties, and nothing of value for its prevention or cure. Any study which may elucidate the pathogenesis of arteriosclerosis is, therefore, of value; and it is to this end that the present experiment was designed.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pathology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of educational practices in the schools on the Island of Montreal.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It must have occurred meny timsto anyone oonneoted with or interested in our rather unique educational. "status quo" here in Montreal how valuable em beooticial it would be tor all or us it each of us knew just what was actually taking place in his neighbor's classroom. This thesis is a humble beginning· step in that general direction. To the best or the author's knowledge no one else has enjoyed the privilege or making e study or conditions in all three of the Montreal gr~ings - English-Catholic. French-Catholic and Protestant - or it they have, do not seem to have published their findings. This thesis represents the final results of' a personal investigation, retined by reading and discussion, ot the educational practices actually anployed and found in tm classrooms or the abovementioned groups.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Education -- Québec (Province) -- Montréal.
Education -- Québec (Province).
Teaching.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The resolution of 1-(4-chlorohenyl)-2,2,2-trichloroethanol : some chemical and insecticidal studies on the separated alcholols.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The compound l,l-di(4-chlorophenyl)-2,2,2-trichloroethane.(DDT I) has assumed great imrortanca with the discovery by the Geigy Chemical Company that it is a vary potent contact insecticide. Their results are surrnnarized in a paper by Lauger, Martin and Muller (1). Patents were issued to cover this work (2). To most cow~cn insects, it is the most powerful contact insecticide known. The Geigy paper is chiefly concerned with the testing of a large number of chemicals on various insects. DDT is included in a list of contact insecticides. These materials are effective only when the insect's body mnkes.contact with the chemical.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A critical study of osmometers used for macromolecules and the changes of polyvinyl acetate in oxygen.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Nearly every important property, and especially the mechanical characteristics, of a high polymer is dependent on its molecular weight. The accurate determination of molecular weight is therefore prerequisite to advances in this branch of cherndstry (1). In view of the inadequacy of classical organo-analytical methods, physico-chendcal methods have assumed paramount importance. These methods· include data from the ultra-centrifuge, osmotic pressures, viscosity, lowering of freezing points, etc. Of these, lowering of freezing point can not be used for molecular weights above 5000, at which point the order of magnitude of the effect becomes so small as to make its use impracticable. The ultra-centrifuge is lindted in use on account of the large initial expense of the apparatus. The viscosity method, as a result of its extreme simplicity, has been used extensively in industry. However, the inherent uncertainty as to the interpretation of the results limits its value very strictly. The present work, therefore, in addition to viscometric data, includes the use of the osmotic method, which suffers tram the foregoing difficulties to a much less extent.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L’actualité politique dans "Les hommes de bonne volonté" (volumes I à XIV) de Jules Romains.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: L'actualite politique n'est qu'un aspect du vaate tableau que Romains fait de la societe fran~aise au cours de la periode 1908 - 1914, mais elle est si souvent melee a la vie doa parsonnages qu'elle parait devoir meriter une etude particuliare. Loraqu'un ecrivain se propose d'etudier l'histoire de la vie d'une societe, il lui fait considerer et les faits euxmemes et l'attitude des hommes envers ces faits. Dans Les Hommes de Bonne Volonte, Romains a reuni une quantite de faits politiques et un grand nombre de personnages qui representant des attitudes differentes envers lea hommes et lea evenements de leur temps. La question est alors posee de savoir dans quelle mesure sa presentation correspond aux idees personnelles de 1'auteur.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Romains, Jules, 1885-1972. Hommes de bonne volunté.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The revision of international conventions.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The interval between the two World Wars has witnessed the rise of various new trends in the sphere of international politics. It has seen the creation of the League or Nations which was interpreted by many to be the corner-stone of a system of collective security based on the respect or international obligations legally contracted. It has seen nations seeking, in the name of collective security, to maintain at all costs the then existing balance or powers. It has seen other nations trying, also in the name of collective security, to bring about change in what they considered to be an unequal and dangerous status-quo. states turned "revisionist" as others were branded "satiated states". [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: International agencies -- Rules and practice.
Peaceful change (International relations).
International law.
Treaties -- Revision.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development of a logarithmic indicating instrument for the measurement of radio noise voltages encountered in radio receivers.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A meter for the measuring of radio noise should give results which are comparable with the effect of the noise as heard in the loudspeaker of a radio receiver and at the same time be accurate and rapid in operation. Radio noise from different types of apparatus differs in character; some types of noise have high amplitude but are of short duration, whereas others are more nearly sinusoidal in form. Furthermore the characteristics of the radio receiver upon which the noise impinges will have an effect on the noise characteristics, so that the wave shape of the noise pulse at the output of the receiver may differ materially from that at the input.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mental factors in leadership from early to late adolescence.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: There was once a time when it was the fashionable thing for orators and debaters to argue whether history created great men, or whether history was created by great men. Although, as Kimball Young (76) has pointed out, the topic bore a close resemblance to the futile and fruitless "chicken or egg" controversy, its existence was justified in that it was instrumental in attracting the attention of men to the importance of studying the phenomenon of leadership. During the past few decades political organizations, industry, labor, and the military have recognized the importance of leadership in the further development of their causes. Concomitantly, there has developed an awareness of the necessity of training for leadership. Bogardus (7), Partridge (62) and Lindeman (38) have stressed that leadership is an important phenomenon in a democracy, and that we must train for leadership.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Leadership.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The reform of education for boys as reflected in eighteenth century English literature.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A fact which impresses one in looking back upon education in England in the eighteenth century from the vantage ground of the twentieth is the inadequate and the haphazard provision for the training of children. The explanation of this fact is to be found mainly in the belief, prevalent then, that edttcation was not one of the functions of government. The only form of instruction in which the central government showed any interest was that given in the schools of industry; these were the sole educational institutions supported by government taxation. 2 It is true that, as ,. the century advanced, voices began to be heard urging that the government should institute a national system of education.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English literature -- 18th century -- History and criticism.
Education in literature.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Investigations of brown heart in swedes.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The results obtained from the study of brown heart in field grown swedes for the years 1935 to 1945 inclusive, are reported, together with the results of greenhouse experiments. This work has been carried out in cooperation between the Departments of Agronomy and Plant Pathology. The months of August and September are critical with respect to brown heart development. The disorder is positively correlated with the amount of precipitation received during these two months and negatively correlated with the hours of sunshine. Brown heart develops very rapidly with the greatest increase occurring over a one to two week period in the middle of August. The varieties Corning and Ditmars possess a fair degree of resistance. Borax sprays applied to the foliage are superior to soil applicitions of borax as a method of controlling brown heart. Potassiurn accentuated boron deficiency in sand cultures, but in the single field trial reported its effect was not significant.Roots that are selected for seed production should be free or brown heart.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on butadiene polymerization.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The majority of the polymer used for the production of synthetic rubber products an the American Continent is obtained by the emulsion eopolymerization of butadiene and styrene. In practice, it has been found necessary to stop the reaction af'ter 80% conversion of the monomers. owing to formation of insoluble gel at higher conversions. Hence, recovery of unreaoted monomers from the reaction system is an economic necessity, representing a considerable proportion of the plant equipment and operation encountered in commercial production of the polymer. In both the styrene and the butadiene recovery systems insoluble, so-called, popcorn polymers are for.med which differ from the previously known polymers of' these compounds whose properties have been extensively investigated (1).[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of extraneous elements in the micro-quantitative analysis of boron.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: By measuring the intensity of a boron line excited in the presence of different elements it was found that those elements which have tines of just longer wavelength than any boron line arising from the same upper energy level. as the one being measured and which are due to transitions between two excited states, the upper of which is not excited at the voltage being used, lessen the intensity of the boron line. The energy is transferred from the boron atom by collisions between the atoms of the two elements. In an arc the concentration of the dampening eleffient depends upon the volatility of the compound form1in which it is used, and the reduction caused therefor varies from compound to compound. This is not so for the spark. The addition of a third element with a line of just shorter wavelength than both the boron and the dampening line and which is excited at the voltage beine used, lessens the dampening effect.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The vapor phase dehydration of ketones and glycols.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The launching of a vast synthetic rubber procram following the loss early in the Pacific war of the United Nations' source of natural rubber, led to an exhaustive investigation of all possibJe methods for the production of butadiene (1). One of the avenues of approach was that of high temperature, vapor-phase catalysis. By this means, the production of olefins, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, esters, and the carrying out of a variety of other types of organic reactions has been accomplished. It has believed that this type of reaction might be a fruitful source of both butadiene and styrene, the chief components of the particular synthetic rubber favored by the Government in its program.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The nitration of polyamides.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This investigation was undertaken in an attempt to prepare an explosive with certain satisfactory plastic and adhesive properties. It seemed most likely that these properties would be obtained in a nitrated polymeric compound. The polyamides of succinic, malic, and tartaric acids were prepared, and the products of their nitration were investigated. It was found that a satisfactory succinic acid - ethylene diamine polymer could be prepared, and could easily be nitrated. The product, though possessive of detonating qualities, was not adequately stable for use as a military explosive. DiffiCulties were encountered in the preparation of satisfactory polymers from maliC and tartaric acids with ethylene diamine, due to the presence of the substituent hydroxy groups. However, an interesting and original study of the relative behaviour of these compounds was made.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Kinetic studies on the formation of hexamine
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Rate curves have been determined for the reagtion of ammonia and formaldehyde in aqueous solution at 0 c. and 35 c., over a range of initial mole ratios {formaldehyde: ammonia) of 0.25 to 2.0. For each set of conditions, three curves have been obtained on the basis of ammonia consumed, formaldehyde consumed and material precipitated with mercuric chloride. At o0 c. the three rate curves tend to approximate one another in a large excess of runmonia but are widelg separated in excess formaldehyde. The reverse is true at 35 c. The reaction is characterized by a high initial rate of formation of hexamine, this rapid rate being maintained to a lower yield of hexamine the more dilute the solution. Ihe existence of a stable by-product in excess formaldehyde is indicated by the variation in final yields of hexamine, when these are calculated on the basis of formaldehyde consumed, ammonia consumed, or material precipitated by mercuric chloride.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hexamine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A nitroguanidine-formaldehyde explosive polymer of resin type. Crystal size-reduction of nitroguanidine by acidic formaldehyde solution.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The problem may be divided according to the following use : (a) A product which oan be employed as a phlegmatizer for high explosives. (b) A product which can be used as a binder in burning mixtures. (·c) A product which can be used to give crystalline high explosives a fluidity suitable for shell-pouring and which sets to form a rigid mass.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: War research. : The mechanism of the direct nitrolysis of hexamine.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A kinetic study of RDX formation by the direct nitrolysls of hexamine indicates strongly that nitracidium ion is the active nitrolyzing agent. The rate of nitrolysis increases rapidly as the molar ratio of nitric acid to hexamine is increased, and continues to do so after the molar ratio is raised above that required for maximum yields. An upper limit to the initial rate exists at extremely high molar ratios. Maximum yields of RDX are obtainable with nitric acid of all concentrations down to 88 per cent if sufficient nitric acid is used. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.
